title: Making (Big) Data

author: Márta Nagy-Rothengass, DG Communications Networks, Content and Technology (CNECT), European Commission

segmentation: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen.
Welcome back to the second day.
I hope you haven't.
You enjoyed the first day of the conference.
You had good talks and you enjoyed also the dinner.
Yesterday night.
The veterans of the EDF might miss something.
Because normally we are announcing at the idea of lunch dinner.
Sorry there will be the next addition of the EDF and you to the facilities.
It was very difficult to give you this information yesterday, so I would like to inform you that the steering committee has welcomed and promoted the next idea of to Luxembourg.
The next event will take place most likely in October.
In auspice of the Luxembourgish presidency the local channels and the local organizers will be enriched Dog Research Institute.
We have slimmed Turkey on board Slim are you in the room if not by the closing session he will come on the stage so you can see him.
We have already set although also the first step of the organizing of the next.
Conference.
And we will have some continuation and we will have also new faces in the chairmanship and in the organizing committee.
I spare the tanks and the high appreciations for the very hard and very excellent work of this organizing and chairs for the EDF for the end of the session.
But at this stage also, thank you very much special thing to Manolis and to Martin at this stage.
And I would like to announce also that the next shares of the EDF 2015 will be Manolis.
He will ensure the continuation.
So thank you very much.
Also for this and knew face will be Jens Lehmann.
Yes, are you in the room?
Not so then we will call you on this stage before we will close the conference.
After ensuring that we have this continuation.
Of the ADF, it's also important to ensure a continuation between the work of yesterday and today, as you might have seen in the agenda on the top on the topic is now to discuss the PPP.
To ensure continuation and Commissioner Kroes, Vice president of the Commission, has called the Community yesterday to work very hard on a very high community.
Quality to what European public private partnership.
I would like in the next few minutes introduce you.

How do we believe from the Commission side that data big data would an should work for Europe and then we would like to hear from a high level panel some inputs and further information on it to the audience.
What are the main goals and the main challenges to be met following this session, which will be a networking session?
Everyone of you he's interested.
To join in or to contribute to a consultation process should choose this room and join that so.
Chen what do we mean with big data after the first day of the conference?
I'll keep it here for record, but skip it.

We have concluded yesterday in many of the sessions that the beta the data has become a social asset with high economic value and it will be a norm important for Europe to work towards a well functioning data ecosystem and a sustainable data economy.
Why is it import?
And just to recall a few elements of the yesterday discussions, it is important because it contributes to the growth.
It enables us new jobs.
It has the biggest growth share of all economic sectors in the world.
It can speed up innovation, and the focus should be ugly on innovation in societal challenges and industry.
It help growing more companies, small and medium sized companies.
It offers a kind of symbiosis for small and big companies in the ICT sector and in the different other sectors.
And it helps us to address the main societal challenges, just to mention two of them.
For example, the cities and the health.
Don this is a picture of a medium size industry companies showing the different systems which are not interoperable, which are a very chaotic in to manage.
And this is the situation today in a relatively value organized SMEs.
Extreme diversity, no Accessibility.
Compatibility between the different tools, and this is one of the challenges which we need to face also in different areas.
But if we speak about tools and systems, we are speaking already somehow about structured data.
But we also concluded yesterday that most of our data is unstructured one in societal sectors, but also in private and and also the business sector.
It will be also very important to worked over its data reuse opportunities to develop a data supply chain.
Nowadays the data is held in small islands.
They are disconnected if we want to link crossing this data and get additional knowledge, we have to ensure that these islands are somehow connected and they will bring us new opportunities.
For these we will need different analytics tools and data mining.
Also, other infrastructure elements to be able to come to decision support systems, visual visualized, other data, products and services.
The data and big data is also very well fitting to the high level European policies.
The Europe 2020 ambitions goal could not be met if we ignore the data driven innovation.

The digital agenda explicitly mentioned not only research innovation but also the open data and open public data resources to reuse, and the Council already 2011 called for the digital single market, including the Public Sector Information Data and Beyond.

If we recall the conclusions of the October Council, we see that one of the main elements has been to enhancing the potential of the data driven innovation to increase the better their productivity and better services to work.

To revise the digital single market, we had a whole session yesterday on interoperability and digital single market to improve the public services, but also to enable other cross sector and cross border services and to look for better coordination of grants, better coordination of work.
And hereby we see a very important role also for an upcoming partnership.

Other actions were supporting an underlying activities in setting up the broadband cloud computing infrastructure network of digital coordinators in the Member States to ensure synergies between the national, the European and the business funding and activities, and to support education.
We have learned that the data community economy will require a diversity and multidisciplinarity of the.
Future data workers.
Data scientists.
We need to work to avoid it and enable in Europe this last but not least, interoperability of platforms and.
ETA will be very important where we are known, broad consultation vast strategy already 2012 end of the year in 2013 on a strategy last year.
The vice president, Crose unknown state the European data value chain strategy at the ICT conference in Vilnius, Anne.
She called for European public Partner Public Partnership and collaboration, sorry.
It was immediately followed by a memorandum for collaboration by Nessie, the European Technology platform driving behind the Big Data and work towards strategic research and innovation.
Agenda has started, which went on even over Christmas and New Year days, so it was really amazing to see it.
Additionally, broad research, innovation, funding and coordination has started and has been ongoing and we will ensure.
Echostage 2020 thank you.
Data challenge addressing.
A European strategy will address the partnership on the data value chain to uptake the new data services and develop new data products.
Innovative spaces.
New World class applications, and.
Different goals, but is also very important for this upcoming partnership to start.

By looking at the existing and ongoing policy activities not to start by zero, we would need that and this, but to consider what from the ongoing policy activities at National and European level could be uptaken just to give you a few examples, the open data strategy PSSI directive is science development, E governance he held but also broadband or their ongoing CPS.
In 5G or manufacturing they are giving a very good support and they should.
It should be a kind of building block and kind of fundamental for our work.

It would be important also to collaborate with future Internet to use the cloud partnership and the enabling infrastructure which is there in Europe also to collaborate with the Grand Coalition for Skills because they have also already started some act.
It is.
That should be addressed at this PPP.
I am sure you will be discussing it much more detailed in the panel, but it will be important to discuss policy and regulatory issues to setup and data friendly environment.
For these.
I do not give the examples.
It will come in the panel and to work towards a European data ecosystem including interoperability and also as a special element addressing the multilingualism of Europe.
If we speak about data in Europe.
It is in most of the cases international and multilingual.
If we speak about Commerce, if we speak about societal challenges, if we go abroad, we would need our help data in possibly in the country which we are visiting.
But at the next steps, the panel discussion just following the networking session as indicated in the next session.
Very will launch a consultation and agreement process for the Strategic research agenda with the goal to conclude it by end of May and in parallel.
Starting setting up the partnership process.

I would also like to invite inform you that Additionally to the PPP work Member States active already in the data field have asked us and supported us very strongly and thank you very much for this special support to set up a workshop.
Also for Member States and we will have tomorrow as an on site event of the Conference of Workshop with Member State representatives called Pioneers in Data Driven Innovation.
I would like to really to show you that.
Any level we are thinking together and we want to ensure that Europe has a very strong strategy.
Here by.
Visio this I would like to thank you for your attention and hand over the floor to certain who is the chair of the panel.
Thank you very much.
